WOExpandedResults.Name: Expanded roll results
WOExpandedResults.Label: Beschreibungen von Roll-Ergebnissen standardmäßig immer anzeigen

FITD.DowntimeActionHint:
Braue Tränke und andere alchemische Substanzen
Baue Schlösser, Fallen, Tricks und Räume.
Kontaktiere Scheußliche Partner, NPCs oder Fraktionen.
Erschaffe Ein Objekt, Vorteil oder eine Vorrichtung.
Beschwöre ein Ritual.
Rekrutiere neue Lakaien.
Foltere einen Gefangenen.
FITD.DowntimeActionRiskIt: Riskiere es: Würfele eine Auszeit-Aktion neu, aber du verlierst deine dominante Position
FITD.IsPrimalMonsterHint: Nur ankreuzen, falls dies ein Ur-Monster ist
FITD.MissingMaterialsHint: Gibt an, dass dem Raum noch Materialien fehlen, damit er funktionieren kann.
FITD.EntranceHints: Wie sieht der Eingang des Dungeons von draußen kommend aus?
FITD.StructureHints: Woraus bestehen Böden und Wände? Wie sind sie beschaffen?
FITD.LightingHints: Was erleuchtet den Dungeon und wie düster ist er?
FITD.AtmosphericsHints: Welche Geräusche und Gerüche erwarten Besucher?
FITD.HoardHints: Woraus bestehen die Berge an Schätzen in eurem Hort?
FITD.ImpsHints1: Such dir zwei Merkmale aus oder denk' dir deine eigenen aus:
FITD.ImpsHints2: schlau - feige - grausam - gestört - lärmend - dümmlich - mürrisch - lästig

TOOLTIP.Coin:
Du kannst Gold zahlen um:
• Eine Kreatur anzulocken
• Hilfe von einem scheußlichen Partner zu erhalten
• Lakaien eine Auszeit-Aktion ausführen zu lassen
• Lakaien zu rekrutieren
• Lakaien zu upgraden
TOOLTIP.Stress: Sobald die Uhr gefüllt ist, drehst du durch: Du bist sofort gezwungen nach deiner Begierde zu handeln. Fertigkeiten während dieser Aktion zu nutzen kostet dich keine Anspannung.
TOOLTIP.Wicked:
Wähle eine weitere Fertigkeit, wenn diese Leiste voll ist. Streiche 1 XP für jedes der folgenden Dinge an, die du diese Sitzung getan hast:
• Du hast Fortschritte im Masterplan erzielt.
• Du warst an einer Dungeon-Szene von jemand anderem beteiligt.
• Du hast dich wie ein echtes Monster verhalten.
• Du hast deine Ausrüstung oder Vorräte auf kreativie Art verwendet.
TOOLTIP.Reckless:
Erhöhe einen Handlungs-Typ eines Attributs um einen Punkt, wenn diese Leiste voll ist.
Streiche 1 XP an, wenn du entweder
eine blutige Verwundungausgespielt oder durchgedreht bist.
TOOLTIP.Shock: Einmalig -1W auf den nächsten Wurf (wird automatisch berechnet)
TOOLTIP.DarkHeart:
+1W auf einen Wurf. Du kannst nur ein Dunkles Herz pro Wurf nutzen.
Todesurteil: Wenn du mit Dunklen Herzen sterben solltest, kannst du mit letzter Kraft eine finale Aktion ausführen: +1W für jedes Dunkle Herz. Jeder Verbündete, der Zeuge wird, erlangt ein Dunkles Herz.
TOOLTIP.Bloodied: Du hast Schock auf alle Attribute. Verschwindet, wenn jeglicher Schock verschwunden ist. Solltest du im blutigen Zustand eine weitere große Wunde erleiden, stirbst du.
TOOLTIP.BloodiedMinions: Deine Lakaien haben -1W auf alle Würfe, während sie verwundet sind. Sie erholen sich nur während der Erholungsphase.
TOOLTIP.Morale: Du kannst Kampfeslust einsetzen, um +1W auf eine Aktion oder einen Schicksalswurf zu erhalten. Kampfeslust erhälst du von Unheilswürfen oder vom GM für herausragende Momente in der Geschichte.
TOOLTIP.LightTongue:
Du kennst die folgenden Worte in der Gemeinen Zunge:
Du
Eins
Ja
Geh'
Iss
Ich
Zwei
Nein
Tu'
Gib
Uns
Drei
Vielleicht
Stopp
Hol'
Es
Mehr
Jetzt
Töte
Gold
TOOLTIP.GMSize: Wenn sich der Dungeon-Rang erhöht, steigere einen Handlungs-Typ um einen Punkt und wachse in zwei verschiedenen Wachstums-Pfaden. Du kannst außerdem in physischer Größe wachsen, wenn du möchtest.
TOOLTIP.GMSize0: Auf Rang 0 bist du nur ein winziges Jungtier, Humanoide sind dir überlegen.
TOOLTIP.GMSize1: Auf Rang 1 bist du Humanoiden ebenbürtig.
TOOLTIP.GMSize3: Auf Rang 3 bist du Humanoiden überlegen.
TOOLTIP.PleasedXP: Du bekommst weder Böse noch Waghalsige XP. Stattdessen vergibst du am Ende der Sitzung 1 XP an den PC, der dich am meisten erfreut hat. Du kannst wie gewöhnlich Übungs XP erhalten.
TOOLTIP.Guardian: Du bekommst 1 XP für jede Sitzung, in der du weder eine blutige Wunde bekommen noch ausgerastet bist. Sobald du 3 XP besitzt kannst du entweder eine Aktions-Art eines Augenstrahls oder einen Handlungs-Typ um einen Punkt steigern.
TOOLTIP.Skillsscan: Wenn du PRÜFST, erfasst du aufmerksam  die Lage oder suchst nach Informationen.
TOOLTIP.Skillstinker: Wenn du BAUST, fummelst du pfiffig mit oder an einem Gerät, Mechanismus oder einem Gebräu herum.
TOOLTIP.Skillstrick: Wenn du TRICKST, manipulierst, täuschst oder verwirrst du Andere gerissen.
TOOLTIP.Skillsfinesse: Wenn du FINGIERST, nimmst du präzise einen Feind ins Ziel, öffnest Schlösser, nutzt filigrane Werkzeuge oder manövrierst in gefährlichen Strömungen.
TOOLTIP.Skillsskulk: Wenn du PIRSCHST, bewegst du dich heimlich fort oder setzt zu einem hinterlisten Überraschungsangriff an.
TOOLTIP.Skillssmash: Wenn du SCHMETTERST, greifst du kraftstrotzend jemanden oder etwas an.
TOOLTIP.Skillsbanter: Wenn du PLÄNKELST, bringst du Andere auf sympathische Art dazu, dir zu helfen - weil du ihnen gefällst.
TOOLTIP.Skillsinvoke: Wenn du HERBEIRUFST, arbeitest du magisch mit dunklen, mystischen Kräften.
TOOLTIP.Skillsthreaten: Wenn du DROHST, bringst du Andere energisch dazu, dir zu gehorchen oder dich zu fürchten.

FITD.RollTokenDescription: Wähle deinen Wurf-Typ und Anzahl der Würfel:
FITD.DeadlyPosition: Würfel, um dem Tod zu entrinnen
FITD.ActionsHelp:
Beistehen: +Wirkung, aber erleidet Konsequenz mit
Aufs Ganze gehen: +Wirkung, aber -Position
Zusammenarbeiten:Das höchste Ergebnis zählt, aber jeder PC mit 5 oder weniger bekommt Anspannung.
Dunkler Handel: +1W für eine unvermeidliche Konsequenz
Dunkles Herz:+1W für den Wurf
FITD.ProjectsHelp:
•BraueTränke und andere alchemische Substanzen.
•Baue Schlösser, Fallen, Tricks und Räume.
•Kontaktiere Scheußliche Partner, NPCs oder Fraktionen.
•Erschaffe ein Objekt, Vorteil oder eine Vorrichtung.
•Beschwöre ein Ritual.
•Rekrutiere neue Lakaien.
•Foltere einen Gefangenen.

• Geh' aufs Ganze!
Würfel eine Auszeit-Aktion neu, aber du verlierst deine dominante Position.
FITD.Name: Name
FITD.CheckboxExample: Enter text to display a checkbox
FITD.BESkillNameHint: Name to show up next to the skill dots
FITD.BESkillTooltipHint: Tooltip to show when hovering over the name

BEWITCH.Name: Bewitchment Ray
BEWITCH.Tooltip: Makes the target act to help you in some way.

DEATH.Name: Death Ray
DEATH.Tooltip: Harms any living thing it hits, necrotizing flesh and plant matter.

FEAR.Name: Fear Ray
FEAR.Tooltip: Strikes fear in their heart, pushing them towards irrational action.

NULL.Name: Null-Magic Ray
NULL.Tooltip: Creates a small area inside which magic does not function.

PARA.Name: Paralysis Ray
PARA.Tooltip: Wrecks a target's nerves, temporarily paralyzing them.

TELE.Name: Telekinesis Ray
TELE.Tooltip: Moves objects and other non-living, solid matter.

TIME.Name: Time Ray
TIME.Tooltip: Modifies time, speeding it up or slowing it down, in a limited bubble.

TRANS.Name: Transmogr. Ray
TRANS.Tooltip: Shapes inanimate objects into new forms.

VISION.Name: Vision Ray
VISION.Tooltip: Sees the unseeable, such as through walls or at great distances.

FITD.HirelingPassiveHint: (leave empty to grant a single move)

DO.Critical: Ja, und… ! Du bekommst was du willst und noch einen Bonus obendrauf!
DO.Mixed: Ja, aber… Du bekommst, was du wolltest, aber zu einem Preis: Du musst mit Konsequenzen rechnen - oder das Ergebnis deiner Aktion ist weniger effektiv als erwartet.
DO.Failure: Nein, und… Die Dinge laufen so schlecht wie nur möglich. Du versagst und die Konsequenzen lassen nicht lange auf sich warten.

ACTION.Name: Aktions-Wurf
ACTION.Critical: Ja, und… ! Du bekommst was du willst und noch einen Bonus obendrauf!
ACTION.Mixed: Ja, aber… Du bekommst, was du wolltest, aber zu einem Preis: Du musst mit Konsequenzen rechnen - oder das Ergebnis deiner Aktion ist weniger effektiv als erwartet.
ACTION.Failure: Nein, und… Die Dinge laufen so schlecht wie nur möglich. Du versagst und die Konsequenzen lassen nicht lange auf sich warten.

BLOWBACK.Name: Rückschlags-Wurf
BLOWBACK.Critical: Jeder PC erlangt ein Dunkles Herz. Zudem könnt ihr ihr eine andere Fraktion die Schuld auf sich nehmen lassen.

CALAMITY.Name: Unheils-Wurf
CALAMITY.Critical: Deine Lakaien bekommen Kampfeslust und können sich zudem freiwillig dem nächsten Überfall anschließen. Zudem machen eure Teufelchen eine erfolgreiche Entdeckung!.
CALAMITY.Success: Your minions gain morale and join the next raid for free.

DEFENSIVE.Name: Defensive Move Roll
DEFENSIVE.Critical: They fully resist it and immediately make a free offensive move.
DEFENSIVE.Mixed: They partially resist it, reducing it in severity.

DISCOVERY.Name: Discovery Roll
DISCOVERY.Critical: A success should clearly improve the dungeon or make the PCs lives better. They're usually placed in the perfect area to best help out the dungeon. A critical counts as two successes!
DISCOVERY.Success: A success should clearly improve the dungeon or make the PCs lives better. They're usually placed in the perfect area to best help out the dungeon.
DISCOVERY.Mixed: A mixed should be light in impact, perhaps a little good or bad for the PCs depending on how they respond to it. They're usually placed in areas of slight inconvenience.
DISCOVERY.Failure: A failure should clearly hurt your dungeon, causing immediate problems for you or making dungeon defense more difficult. They're almost always placed in positions that make it easier for invaders to bypass defenses or interfere with your layout.

ENGAGEMENT.Name: Engagement Roll
ENGAGEMENT.Critical: You start with the upper hand, in control of the situation. Also, you get a lucky turn of events!
ENGAGEMENT.Success: You start with the upper hand, in control of the situation.
ENGAGEMENT.Mixed: You start on equal footing, ready to face the challenge.
ENGAGEMENT.Failure: You start in a tight spot, with consequences being inflicted.

LOCK.Name: Lock Roll
LOCK.Critical: Each adventurer wastes a move trying to open it, then they go another way unless they have no other option.
LOCK.Success: An adventurer wastes a move trying to open it, then they go another way unless they have no other option.
LOCK.Mixed: They go another way unless they have no other option.
LOCK.Failure: They unlock the door and move past it.
LOCK.Note: ❖ When there is no other way forward, roll again for the lock.

LOOT.Name: Loot Roll
LOOT.Critical: You may combine two successes into a Critical to pull a powerful item from the loot. The GM chooses what it is.
LOOT.Success: You pull a mundane or valuable item from the loot.
LOOT.Mixed: You gain 1 gold or spend it on revelry instead.
LOOT.Failure: You enjoy some revelry, gaining a dark heart.
LOOT.Note: If you gain excess dark hearts, you overdo it, suffering a frustrating or devastating consequence based your revelry!

RESISTANCE.Name: Resistance Roll
RESISTANCE.Critical: You clear 1 stress and fully resist the consequence.
RESISTANCE.Success: You spend 1 stress to fully resist the consequence.
RESISTANCE.Mixed: You spend 2 stress to partially resist the consequence.
RESISTANCE.Failure: You spend 3 stress to partially resist the consequence.

RESISTDEATH.Mixed: The consequence is reduced in severity but still devastating. Maybe you get knocked out of the scene, a clock starts as you start bleeding to death, or you lose a limb.
RESISTDEATH.Failure: You die. If you have dark hearts, perform your death knell!

CREATURE.Name: Creature Roll
CREATURE.Critical: You damage two adventurers of your choice. Roll again.
CREATURE.Success: You damage an adventurer of your choice. Roll again.
CREATURE.Mixed: You damage an adventurer of the GM's choice and the creature is knocked out of the fight.
CREATURE.Failure: The creature is slain or flees the dungeon for good.
CREATURE.Note: ❖ You can't damage the same adventurer twice in a row unless they're alone.

TRAP.Name: Trap Roll
TRAP.Critical: You damage two adventurers of your choice. Roll again.
TRAP.Success: You damage an adventurer of your choice. Roll again.
TRAP.Mixed: You damage an adventurer of the GM's choice.
TRAP.Failure: The trap is disabled or avoided by the adventurers.
TRAP.Note: You can't damage the same adventurer twice in a row unless they're alone.

STARTING.Name: Starting Location Roll
STARTING.Success: A success starts you off in a good position. You begin in the exact dungeon room you want to be in with weapons nearby.
STARTING.Mixed: A mixed starts you off in a less than ideal situation. You might not have weapons or maybe just not begin in a great location. You're likely busy doing some other task.
STARTING.Failure: A failure starts you off in a terrible position. You're far from the action, rather distracted by something you're doing, likely without weapons, or maybe even sleeping. The adventurers have a decisive advantage against you.

PATHING.Name: Pathing Roll
PATHING.Success: On a mixed or success, the adventurers go the way the players want them to.
PATHING.MixedSuccess: On a mixed or success, the adventurers go the way the players want them to.
PATHING.Failure: On a mixed or success, the adventurers go the way the players want them to. On a failure, they go the other way.

FORTUNE.Name: Fortune Roll
FORTUNE.Critical: It's an ideal situation as you get what you were hoping for. Also, you get more than you were hoping for!
FORTUNE.Success: It's an ideal situation as you get what you were hoping for.
FORTUNE.Mixed: It's pretty good, but not perfect, with a tinge of disappointment.
FORTUNE.Failure: Things go about as poorly as they could.

HINT.CreaturePrompt: Describe an unintelligent monster and two traits:
HINT.CreatureParagraph: clever, corrupted, corrosive, diseased, incorporeal, flaming, freezing, magical, oozing, sneaky, strong, swarming, terrifying, tireless, venomous
HINT.LockPrompt: Describe the door materials and the lock mechanism
HINT.LockParagraph1: Door materials: bars, bone, crystal, ice, iron, magical field, roots, stone, wood
HINT.LockParagraph2: Lock mechanisms: arcane, bar, bolt, heavy object, mortise, lock, padlock, password, pulley, pressure plate, puzzle, rim lock, timed
HINT.TrapPrompt: Describe the mechanism and its trigger
HINT.TrapParagraph1: Mechanisms: crushing wall, darts, spikes, fire, boulder, sawblade, pendulum blade, gas, lightning coil, lightning arc, swing blade, explosive barrel, pitfall, floor blade
HINT.TrapParagraph2: Triggers: pressure plate, tripwire, magical detection, illusion or disguise, sound, item removal, false door
HINT.TrickPrompt: Describe an intent and its trigger.
HINT.TrickParagraph: Each trick has an intent, something that happens to the adventurers, and a trigger which causes the trick to happen.

PHASE1.Name: Recovery
PHASE1.Hint1: All stress, Shock and Bloodied condition clear.
PHASE1.Hint2: Used supply slots and defenses clear.
PHASE1.Hint3: Once per cycle abilities, items, and rooms refresh.
PHASE1.Hint4: Recovery happens after invasions that occur from blowback.

PHASE2.Name: Loot Roll
PHASE2.Hint1: Roll a number of dice equal to the amount of loot you hauled in from your last raid.
PHASE2.Hint2: Each die rolled gives you something based on its result.
PHASE2.Hint3: May combine two successes into a critical for a powerful item chosen by the GM.
PHASE2.Hint4: Gaining excess Dark Hearts causes monsters to overdo their revelry.
PHASE2.Hint5: Overdoing it causes damage to the monsters or the dungeon in a frustrating or devastating consequence.

PHASE3.Name: Downtime
PHASE3.Hint1: Each player gets one downtime action, plus any extra from calling abilities.
PHASE3.Hint2: Players can pay their minions 1 gold to perform a downtime action.
PHASE3.Hint3: Downtime actions are usually made with dominant position. (Torture is an expection)
PHASE3.Hint4: Risk It: Players can reroll any dominant downtime action with normal position instead.
PHASE3.Hint5: The GM rolls the dungeon tier for the imps’ downtime action.

PHASE4.Name: Dungeon Logic Review
PHASE4.Hint1: 5 factors determine the amount of malcontent in the Dungeon. The GM needs to build a gut feeling for this dungeon logic
PHASE4.Hint2: Atmosphere: Does the layout feel like a dungeon and do the minions enjoy living there? They want your dungeon to make sense, feel like a dungeon, and have at least some rooms that they can enjoy. They desire a place that feels evil and dungeony.
PHASE4.Hint3: Growth: Has the dungeon been steadily growing, increasing in tier and adding rooms and discoveries? They yearn for power as much as their masters do because belonging to a strong dungeon means greater raids and more revelry.
PHASE4.Hint4: Hierarchy: Are weaker creatures likely to face adventurers before stronger ones? Powerful monsters, such as upgraded minions, think it’s beneath them to face the enemy first.
PHASE4.Hint5: Loot and Revelry: Has there been a steady flow of loot into the dungeon and has the dungeon survived your revelry intact? Making sure you go out of your way to increase loot rolls helps keep grumbling down.
PHASE4.Hint6: Worthy Masters: Have you formulated a solid master plan and garnered a reputation of evil? You have to present a strong front and any chinks in that armor quickly become apparent to those below you.

PHASE5.Name: Calamity Roll
PHASE5.Hint1: GM rolls 1-3 dice depending on how much the Denizens are grumbling.
PHASE5.Hint2: Sample calamities are weak or normal dungeon invasions, denizen trouble, structural problems and outside interference.

PHASE6.Name: Calamity
PHASE6.Hint1: The GM decides what form the calamity takes.
PHASE6.Hint2: It can be something that is immediately accepted and resolved or you can jump into a scene to try to deal with the fallout of the situation.
PHASE6.Hint3: Calamity can’t be resisted and may be pocketed by the GM and brought out at an opportune time later.
PHASE6.Hint4: Minor calamity is an inconvenience, but one that you’re likely equipped to ignore or handle.
PHASE6.Hint5: Major calamity is an immediately pressing concern that must be dealt with.

PHASE7.Name: Goal + Target
PHASE7.Hint1: Players come up with a goal to pursue. When indecision or disputes arise, use a power struggle to resolve it.
PHASE7.Hint2: Players look for a target that makes sense for their goal.
PHASE7.Hint3: Targets belong to factions, being one small part of the overall faction.
PHASE7.Hint4: You are on equal footing with factions at your tier.  Hitting equal or higher tier targets gives more loot.
PHASE7.Hint5: The GM decides what type of raid scene makes sense. When the goal is not very challenging, it can focus on the approach (Difficulty in getting to the target) or the getaway (Difficulty in getting out of the area).

PHASE8.Name: Plan + Details
PHASE8.Hint1: Choose a raid plan and set some details.
PHASE8.Hint2: Ambush: Hit them when they least expect it, making sure they don’t take any of you down in the process. Why is their guard down? Where are you waiting? What’s the signal?
PHASE8.Hint3: Assault: Bring full force to bear, driving off or killing all those who stand against you. Where does the assault begin? Who leads the way? Do you avoid any targets?
PHASE8.Hint4: Negotiation: Talk it out, tell lies, or offer something to get what you want, spilling as little blood as possible. Where’s the meeting spot? What are you offering? Are you there in good faith?
PHASE8.Hint5: Stealth: Slip in, find what you’re after, and slip out quietly, being noticed as little as possible. Where do you slip in? What time of day is it? Do you split up?
PHASE8.Hint6: Strike: Bust in, get what you want, and run out quickly, without deviating from your goal. How do you get in? Who signals to get out? What guards your prize?
PHASE8.Hint7: Trickery: Confuse, lure, or trick them into doing what you want, without letting on until it’s too late. What do you want them to do? Why would they do that? Does it matter if they know after?

PHASE9.Name: Engagement Roll
PHASE9.Hint1: The GM rolls engagement, considering the following factors.
PHASE9.Hint2: The dungeon’s tier vs. the target’s faction’s tier.
PHASE9.Hint3: The target is particularly strong/weak against the chosen plan.
PHASE9.Hint4: The PCs are working with good/bad information.
PHASE9.Hint5: The faction has been hit by the dungeon before or they’re caught unaware.
PHASE9.Hint6: Recent events in the sandbox has the faction on the lookout for trouble
PHASE9.Hint7: During a raid, you take +1d to your loot roll for: Target faction at least equal to dungeon tier, each tier target faction is above the dungeon tier, each source of good loot you grabbed, each adventurer taken out.

PHASE10.Name: Raid Plan Review
PHASE10.Hint1: After the raid, review the raid plan together and how well you followed it. The GM is the final judge.
PHASE10.Hint2: Ambush: Minimize your own losses. (1d: You took heavy damage. 2d: There were a few injuries. 3d: Nobody in your group was injured)
PHASE10.Hint3: Assault: Kill or drive off all opposing you. (1d: Significant forces remained when you left. 2d: Most on the scene fled or were killed. 3d: It was a complete slaughter, crushing all)
PHASE10.Hint4: Negotiation: Avoid conflict. (1d: It devolved into a bloody fight. 2d: Things were tense, but nobody died. 3d: You maintained control throughout)
PHASE10.Hint5: Stealth: Avoid being noticed. (1d: You were clearly spotted and identified. 2d: You were spotted, but recovered. 3d: They had no idea of your presence)
PHASE10.Hint6: Strike: Stick to the path and get out quickly. (1d: You got caught up in other endeavors. 2d: There were a few distractions. 3d: You didn’t diverge from the plan once)
PHASE10.Hint7: Trickery: Don’t let on until it’s too late. (1d: They saw right through your intentions. 2d: They did as you wanted, but were suspicious. 3d: They did exactly as you wanted)

PHASE11.Name: Blowback Roll
PHASE11.Hint1: How did the raid plan go? (1d: off the rails, 2d: a little awry, 3d: perfectly)
PHASE11.Hint2: Possible consequences: Weak to strong dungeon invasion, travel trouble, factions/sandbox trouble, ambush / capture.

PHASE12.Name: Blowback
PHASE12.Hint1: Blowback can be something that is immediately accepted and resolved or you can jump into a scene to try to deal with the fallout of the situation.
PHASE12.Hint2: The GM decides what form blowback takes.
PHASE12.Hint3: It can’t be resisted and may be pocketed by the GM and brought out at an opportune time later.
PHASE12.Hint4: Minor blowback is an inconvenience, but one that you’re likely equipped to ignore or handle.
PHASE12.Hint5: Major blowback is an immediately pressing concern that must be dealt with.

ERRORS.NoActorAssigned: No actor is assigned to your player
ERRORS.NoMinionPackLinked: No minion pack was found linked to your actor

GAME_LOGIC._comment: GAME LOGIC DATA: Keep in sync with item name translations
